thread.title: Walkthru: Stage set for Bengals-Steelers ... again
thread.title_full: Walkthru: Stage set for Bengals-Steelers ... again

title: Walkthru: Stage set for Bengals-Steelers ... again
text:
Walkthru: Stage set for Bengals-Steelers ... again Paul Dehner Jr. , pdehnerjr@enquirer.com 8:08 a.m. EDT October 19, 2015 The Bengals and Steelers look to be on a crash course over the last 10 games, plus, judging wins, today's cover, telling stat, red faces, NSFW, snap analysis and plenty of dancing Bengals. The Cincinnati Bengals wide receiver A.J. Green (18) runs the ball after a reception against the Pittsburgh Steelers at Heinz Field. (Photo: Jeff Swinger, The Cincinnati Enquirer) 1 CONNECT 5 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Today's Walkthru is coming to you live at 5 a.m. from the passenger seat of a Mini Cooper that contains three people, two suitcases, one dog and relentless pursuit of returning to Cincinnati before noon. 
As we explore the delightfully flat and barren Western New York countryside I can't help but take this bye week to look forward to what the second half of this season will bring. The first half was spent establishing the Bengals as a legitimate Super Bowl contender. I whispered those words after the 4-0 start. We say them aloud now. They are without debate. 
There's this stat Dan Hoard pointed out in sifting through the rubble yesterday: Since current playoff format started in 1990, 49% of teams that started 6-0 went to the Super Bowl. Not a prediction, just a stat #Bengals — Dan Hoard (@Dan_Hoard) October 18, 2015 
Five undefeated teams remain. The Bengals live among them. Every team – maybe besides the Patriots – have questions about whether or not they can end up there. The Broncos have the aging arm of Peyton Manning, the Bengals an undeniable history of playoff failure. And even the Patriots still must win without the pedigree of Darrelle Revis and Brandon Browner manning their corners. 
The Bengals' drive to finish in the top two and earn a bye will be fun to follow. For me, however, the next 10 weeks now set up to be about one battle: Bengals-Steelers. Pittsburgh's back-to-back wins against San Diego and Arizona without Big Ben should be reason for Bengals fans to take notice. During this time frame this young Pittsburgh defense took major strides. And this offense was already going to be one of the best in football and has yet to play a game with Ben, Le'Veon Bell and Martavis Bryant together this season. 
They are just two games back and welcome the Bengals to Heinz Field Nov. 1 for the first of two AFC North showdowns. 
The Steelers schedule the rest of the way includes: Should win: Browns, @Browns, @Ravens, Raiders Suddenly not so daunting: @Seattle, Indianapolis Game-changers: Bengals, @Bengals, Broncos 
As for the Bengals schedule the rest of the way, we originally thought this would be a brutal gauntlet through the league, but as happens every year, perspective changes weekly. For me, the Bengals remaining 10 games split into a clear haves and have nots this year. Should win: @49ers, Texans, Browns, @Browns, Ravens Suddenly not so daunting: Game-changers: Steelers, @Steelers, @Broncos, Rams, @Arizona 
If we want to start getting truly presumptuous, you can speculate the Bengals should go at least 4-1, if not 5-0 against the top five games considering how easily they've handled lesser opponents this year. Toss in three games against Denver, St. Louis and Arizona then you hope to 2-1 in those. That leaves the Steelers to decide the difference between the range of 14-2 and 11-5. The latter could very easily turn 6-0 into a road playoff game in the first round again. 
This, of course, was the same scenario last year. Had the Bengals won even one of the two games against Pittsburgh, they would have been hosting a playoff game and AFC North champs for the second straight season. Instead, they were disposed on the road at Indy in Round 1. 
When talking about Super Bowl contenders in this top-heavy AFC, the path to do much more than earn the first playoff win in 24 years, swings dramatically based on how the Bengals handle Pittsburgh. 
They have two weeks to prepare for Round 1. 
ON TAP TODAY 
Bengals go through film review. First of early week practices before the team takes off for the bye week, returning Monday. 
TWITTER QUESTION OF THE DAY Do you think the credibility of this win is slightly "slanted" due to Tyrod not playing? @pauldehnerjr — Tim (@YaAlreadyKnowIt) October 18, 2015 
Thanks for the question, Dan. 
Funny how our view of the season changes. Sure, Tyrod Taylor had his moments this year, but what are we really talking about? The Bills weren't missing Jim Kelly circa-1992. The difference between Manuel and Taylor could maybe be a few gutsy runs and the periodic downfield pass. Did you see Bills games this year? With Taylor they scrapped and clawed for 14 points against Tennessee. The Bengals and Bills weren't remotely close Sunday. Even the 34-21 score would be deceiving to a game that was rarely in doubt. 
SPORTS COVER 
Great photo from our man on the scene Kareem Elgazzar of Gio Bernard smiling on his way to the end zone. What tomorrow's Enquirer sports section will look like. For more Bengals coverage, go to: http://t.co/2OcIDHKvQI pic.twitter.com/3T84WhFhbs — Enquirer (@Enquirer) October 19, 2015 
IN CASE YOU MISSED IT 
Analysis: Why the Bengals Beat the Bills. Plus, videos, vines, photos, game ball, upon further review, key numbers, revisiting three keys and I go to Buffalo hometown legend Rick James for the song of the game. 
JIm-O on the Bengals rise to AFC heavyweights. 
C. Trent on Marvin Jones, the fourth different player in as many weeks to lead the Bengals in receiving yards. 
The Bengals offensive line shut down a quarter-billion dollar defensive front. Just the latest in a three-game gauntlet run that should make those across the league perk up an notice they are among the best lines in football. 
REACTION VIDEO 
The cold portion of the season is officially here. Thanks, Buffalo. Watch Jim and I gradually turn from flesh to blue red in our faces over the course of four minutes talking about this Bengals win. Bengals writers Paul Dehner Jr. and Jim Owczarski break down the team's 34-21 victory in Buffalo. The Enquirer/Kareem Elgazzar 
AROUND THE DIVISION
